thread.title: Area Roundup: Korte reaches 1,000 career kills at Bishop Mac tourney
thread.title_full: Area Roundup: Korte reaches 1,000 career kills at Bishop Mac tourney

title: Area Roundup: Korte reaches 1,000 career kills at Bishop Mac tourney
text:
Area Roundup: Korte reaches 1,000 career kills at Bishop Mac tourney Morris' Nick McPherson qualifies for state golf Published: Monday, Oct. 12, 2015 10:19 p.m. CDT Caption (Craig Lincoln for Shaw Media) Morris’ Kaylin Korte topped the 1,000 career kill plateau over the weekend at the Bishop McNamara Tournament. Caption (Lathan Goumas - lgoumas@shawmedia.com) Nick McPherson, shown here during the Joliet Park District Junior Golf Championship in July, qualified for the state tournament this weekend by shooting 77 at the Class 2A Nazareth Academy Sectional at Broken Arrow in Lockport. By: STAFF REPORTS 
KANKAKEE – The Morris volleyball team split four matches at the Bishop McNamara Tournament over the weekend, beating Kankakee, 25-17 25-10, and Wilmington, 24-26, 25-17, 15-13, while losing to tourney champ Joliet West, 25-20, 25-19, and Bradley-Bourbonnais, 25-21, 25-12. Related Links Area Roundup: Korte reaches 1,000 career kills at Bishop Mac tourney 
Kaylin Korte, who already owns the school record for kills, added to her total with 56 and, in the process, topped 1,000 for her career. She also had 11 digs and five blocks 
“Kaylin reached her goal of 1,000 varsity kills in the first match,” Morris coach Taylor Lafond said. “It’s a pretty amazing accomplishment and we are proud of her.” 
Janelle Brehm had a total of 22 kills, 14 digs and four blocks, while Ashley Hood had 36 assists and eight digs. Addison Polite had 43 assists, 21 digs, two aces and three kills. 
Ryan Friend had two blocks for the Redskins (12-15-2), while Veronica Johnson had eight. Calleen Soper added seven kills and two blocks and Corrinne Day had nine digs. Katy Smith also had two kills and two blocks. 
BOYS GOLF 
Class 2A Nazareth Academy Sectional: At Broken Arrow in Lockport, Morris finished seventh with a 340 score. However, Morris senior Nick McPherson shot 5-over-par 77 to tie for second behind the 75 of medalist Casey Domke of Marian Catholic and qualify for this weekend’s state meet. 
“I’ve played in a lot of wind, and you just have to trust it,” said McPherson, who will make his second straight trip to state. “I shot what I thought I would on the front [40] and turned it around on the back [37] and fought my way through.” 
Morris’ other counting scores were Jake Hulbert 86, Jared Lines 87 and Jack Galloway 88. 
“For our team to get out, we needed four really good scores,” McPherson said. “It wasn’t what we wanted it to be.” 
“We have four solid players, but it takes everyone to shoot their best and you don’t always get that,” Morris coach Matt Lafond said. 
Class 3A Alton Sectional: Minooka finished fourth with an 18-hole score of 331, 13 strokes away from state qualification. Dan Anfield qualified as an individual for the Indians with an 18-hole score of 77. 
GIRLS GOLF 
Class A Woodridge Sectional: Seneca turned in its best performance of the year with an 18-hole team score of 392. That was good enough for sixth place and missed the third place finish needed for state qualifying by only 11 strokes. 
Sam DeGraaf had the low score for the day for Seneca with a 95, followed by Natalie Hamilton (97), Randi Rohder (97), Taylor Vroman (103), Faith Hacker (102) and Heather Vroman (112). 
“This was a fantastic finish to a very successful season for our Lady Irish program,” Seneca coach Todd Yegge said. “We had great leadership from our senior girls that we will miss next season, a lot of promise for our underclass girls and a lot to look forward to in our future.” 
– Dick Goss of The Joliet Herald-News contributed to this report
